acknowledgments.summary: Michael Heinz and Nafiez reported these vulnerabilities to Siemens.

notes.text: This CSAF advisory was extracted from unstructured data and may contain inaccuracies. If you notice any errors, please reach out to the designated contact at CISA CSAF: central@cisa.dhs.gov
notes.title: CISA Disclaimer

notes.text: All information products included in https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics are provided "as is" for informational purposes only. The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) does not provide any warranties of any kind regarding any information contained within. Further dissemination of this product is governed by the Traffic Light Protocol (TLP) marking in the header. For more information about TLP, see https://us-cert.cisa.gov/tlp/.
notes.title: Legal Notice

notes.text: Successful exploitation of these vulnerabilities could lead the application to crash or lead to arbitrary code execution.
notes.title: Risk evaluation

notes.text: CISA recommends users take defensive measures to minimize the risk of exploitation of this vulnerability. Specifically, users should:
notes.title: Recommended Practices

notes.text:
CISA reminds organizations to perform proper impact analysis and risk assessment prior to deploying defensive measures.
CISA also provides a section for control systems security recommended practices on the ICS webpage on cisa.gov/icsSeveral recommended practices are available for reading and download, including Improving Industrial Control Systems Cybersecurity with Defense-in-Depth Strategies.
notes.title: Recommended Practices

notes.text:
Additional mitigation guidance and recommended practices are publicly available on the ICS webpage on cisa.gov/icsin the Technical Information Paper, ICS-TIP-12-146-01B--Targeted Cyber Intrusion Detection and Mitigation Strategies.
Organizations observing any suspected malicious activity should follow their established internal procedures and report their findings to CISA for tracking and correlation against other incidents.
notes.title: Recommended Practices

notes.text: For further inquiries on security vulnerabilities in Siemens products and solutions, please contact the Siemens ProductCERT: https://www.siemens.com/cert/advisories
notes.title: Additional Resources

references.summary: SSA-360681: Datalogics File Parsing Vulnerabilities in Teamcenter Visualization and JT2Go - CSAF Version
SSA-360681: Datalogics File Parsing Vulnerabilities in Teamcenter Visualization and JT2Go - PDF Version
SSA-360681: Datalogics File Parsing Vulnerabilities in Teamcenter Visualization and JT2Go - TXT Version

notes.text: The APDFL.dll contains a stack-based buffer overflow vulnerability that could be triggered while parsing specially crafted PDF files. This could allow an attacker to execute code in the context of the current process.
notes.title: Summary

remediations.details: Do not open untrusted PDF files in JT2Go and Teamcenter Visualization
Update to V14.1.0.5 or later version
Update to V13.3.0.8 or later version
Update to V14.0.0.4 or later version
Update to V14.1.0.5 or later version

As a general security measure, Siemens strongly recommends to protect network access to devices with appropriate mechanisms. In order to operate the devices in a protected IT environment, Siemens recommends to configure the environment according to Siemens' operational guidelines for Industrial Security (Download: 
https://www.siemens.com/cert/operational-guidelines-industrial-security), and to follow the recommendations in the product manuals.
Additional information on Industrial Security by Siemens can be found at: 
https://www.siemens.com/industrialsecurity

notes.text: The APDFL.dll contains an out of bounds write past the fixed-length heap-based buffer while parsing specially crafted PDF files. This could allow an attacker to execute code in the context of the current process.
notes.title: Summary

cwe.name: Improper Restriction of Operations within the Bounds of a Memory Buffer

notes.text: The APDFL.dll contains a memory corruption vulnerability while parsing specially crafted PDF files. This could allow an attacker to execute code in the context of the current process.
notes.title: Summary
